article_title: Entrepreneurs dazzle, then break for ice cream
article_text:
Entrepreneurs dazzle, then break for ice cream Children's imaginations given free rein as they show entrepreneurial skills in medical innovation competition

Photo: Karen Warren, Staff Erick Drew, 8, Adam Ali, 7, Oscar Case, and Aaniyah Bhola, both 8,...

The first of 20 entrepreneurial teams boldly takes the stage cradling a prototype. Buoyed by confidence in their concept and tamping down last-minute jitters, the four team members make a three-minute pitch to introduce what they hope will be the next big thing in medical devices.

article_metadata.description: Children's imaginations given free rein as they show entrepreneurial skills in medical innovation competition  Buoyed by confidence in their concept and tamping down last-minute jitters, the four team members make a three-minute pitch to introduce what they hope will be the next big thing in medical devices.  Float your way to recovery! Adam Ali booms with the enthusiasm of a late-night infomercial as he holds aloft a contraption called the Air Crutch, designed to ease sore armpits by employing the science of magnetic fields.  In the question-and-answer period that follows, the team is quizzed by doctors, scientists and business leaders from Rice University, the Gensler design firm and the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center about their idea to create an air cushion as two magnets repel each other: one in a padded underarm cuff and another at the top of a crutch that patients hold steady.  [...] it was all quite heady for Team Air Crutch as it took home the Best Pitch prize last month at the medical innovation competition sponsored by the Texas Medical Center's accelerator for business startups.  In a first-time partnership between the Texas Medical Center and Houston's British International School, 80 second-graders (called Year Three in Brit school lingo) took a curriculum on great inventors to the next level by joining the ranks.  [...] pitched was "Baby's Best Friend," a mobile that doubles as a monitor to not only alert parents when baby awakes but tracks heartbeat, temperature, and color of skin.  "Someone once said we enter the education system as question marks and we quickly covert to periods," McKeon says of the restrictions placed on children's imaginations and enthusiasm in school.  Andrea Case-Rogers, mother of one of the Air Crutch kids, watched her son practice his pitch lines at home like he was rehearsing for a school play.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam

[...] pitched was "Baby's Best Friend," a mobile that doubles as a monitor to not only alert parents when baby awakes but tracks heartbeat, temperature, and color of skin.
